raw_results.original: Mammalian hair, also known as pelage, can vary in color between populations, organisms within a population, and even on the individual organism. Light-dark color variation is common in the mammalian taxa. Sometimes, this color variation is determined by age variation, however, in other cases, it is determined by other factors. Selective pressures, such as ecological interactions with other populations or environmental conditions, often lead to the variation in mammalian coloration. These selective pressures favor certain colors in order to increase survival. Camouflage is thought to be a major selection pressure shaping coloration in mammals, although there is also evidence that sexual selection, communication, and physiological processes may influence the evolution of coloration as well. Camouflage is the most predominant mechanism for color variation, as it aids in the concealment of the organisms from predators or from their prey. Coat color can also be for intraspecies communication such as warning members of their species about predators, indicating health for reproductive purposes, communicating between mother and young, and intimidating predators. raw_results.sampled: Mammalian hair , also known as pelage , can vary in color between populations , organisms within a population , and even on the individual organism . Light-dark color variation and color difference within population-level phenotypes have previously been shown to be associated with both genetic and epigenetic factors . In this study we investigated whether color was affected by the number of color variants in individual hair shafts . We found that individuals carrying multiple alleles of single color variants were associated with greater variation in hair color by using whole genome comparative analyses with genomic DNA arrays . Color was in turn correlated with skin pigmentation and with the hair shaft cross-sectional shape . This is the first study that demonstrates how skin pigmentation may affect color across populations , species , and individuals , and how these and other factors may affect the variability of hair color . Moreover , our findings suggest that hair color variation is associated with skin color variation , which may explain the correlation between color and lightness . This study emphasizes the complexity in the phenotypic variation that exists within and between individuals , populations , and communities , and the degree of control of such variation that is exerted via the influence of the underlying genome .

raw_results.original: Boundaries can be inclusive or exclusive depending on how they are perceived by other people. An exclusive boundary arises, for example, when a person adopts a marker that imposes restrictions on the behaviour of others. An inclusive boundary is created, by contrast, by the use of a marker with which other people are ready and able to associate. At the same time, however, an inclusive boundary will also impose restrictions on the people it has included by limiting their inclusion within other boundaries. An example of this is the use of a particular language by a newcomer in a room full of people speaking various languages. Some people may understand the language used by this person while others may not. Those who do not understand it might take the newcomer's use of this particular language merely as a neutral sign of identity. But they might also perceive it as imposing an exclusive boundary that is meant to mark them off from her. On
raw_results.sampled: Boundaries can be inclusive or exclusive depending on how they are perceived by other people . An exclusive boundary arises , for example , when a person adopts a marker that tells others that they are something they are not . This can arise for both individuals and groups within communities . There are both social and individual motivations for creating an exclusive boundary . Sometimes the exclusivity of the boundary is a reaction to something about the others . Sometimes it is to assert a certain sense or set of values or to exclude an opponent . Regardless of why it is done , an exclusive boundary sets limits on how others can interact with you or what you can do together . It is also interesting to note that there are two different kinds of exclusivity involved in a boundary . First is the exclusivity involved in an intentional separation of two people , and second is the exclusivity of the mark . People who are very clear about their own boundaries often feel justified in limiting the extent to which they allow others to cross them . Conversely , the very broad range of personal boundaries that people can have , sometimes known as an `` open '' or `` free '' boundary .

raw_results.original: To maintain a high constant body temperature is energy expensive – mammals therefore need a nutritious and plentiful diet. While the earliest mammals were probably predators, different species have since adapted to meet their dietary requirements in a variety of ways. Some eat other animals – this is a carnivorous diet (and includes insectivorous diets). Other mammals, called herbivores, eat plants. A herbivorous diet includes subtypes such as fruit-eating and grass-eating. An omnivore eats both prey and plants. Carnivorous mammals have a simple digestive tract, because the proteins, lipids, and minerals found in meat require little in the way of specialized digestion. Plants, on the other hand, contain complex carbohydrates, such as cellulose. The digestive tract of an herbivore is therefore host to bacteria that ferment these substances, and make them available for digestion. The bacteria are either housed in the multichambered stomach or in a large cecum. The size of an animal is also a factor in determining diet

Homeothermy in mammals began to develop in early mammals and some groups are closely related to today s rodents . In rodents , the ability to maintain a body temperature is based on a fat metabolism , while other homeothermic mammals ( marsupials ) need to increase their metabolic rates ( i. e. the total number of calories that they take in ) by more than the available free energy ( F ) for them to become more active . As a result , the metabolic rate of carnivorous mammals can be more than a factor of 20 higher than the metabolic rate of other mammal . The major homeothermic groups include some of mammals that are currently living in the arid climes and have no real need of a metabolic rate that varies that much over a single day . The mammals that do vary their metabolic rates quite a bit throughout the day are more closely related to the carnivorous mammals .

raw_results.original: To prevent the risk of out-of-phase supplies mixing, sections of line fed from different feeder stations must be kept strictly isolated. This is achieved by Neutral Sections (also known as Phase Breaks), usually provided at feeder stations and midway between them although, typically, only half are in use at any time, the others being provided to allow a feeder station to be shut down and power provided from adjacent feeder stations. Neutral Sections usually consist of an earthed section of wire which is separated from the live wires on either side by insulating material, typically ceramic beads, designed so that the pantograph will smoothly run from one section to the other. The earthed section prevents an arc being drawn from one live section to the other, as the voltage difference may be higher than the normal system voltage if the live sections are on different phases and the protective circuit breakers may not be able to safely interrupt the considerable current that would flow. To prevent the risk of an arc being drawn across from one
raw_results.sampled: To prevent the risk of out-of-phase supplies mixing , sections of line fed from different feeder stations must be kept strictly isolated . This is achieved by Neutral Sections ( NS ) installed in line and feeder portions of the distribution network ( LINK ) which must remain at a specific voltage and amperage or the power of the load will vary from line to line . For example , a distribution feeder with a nominal power of 10kVA will normally draw 20A continuously without having to reduce its amperage from time to time . With the use of Neutral Bases with a neutral in the distribution feeder , a neutral section is introduced into the feeder portion of the network . In the absence of the Neutral Bases , the network would be operated in the absence of electrical power . Neutral Bases are thus essential to the correct implementation of the electrical supply . All neutral sections also help to ensure that , when multiple generators supply a network , the voltage supplied to the customers can not become unbalanced . For example , a distribution system with 10,000V/12A supplies is balanced when the Loads are divided equally between two generators at voltages of 6KV/24A and 10KV/24A .

Two types of unsaturates are palmitic acid and oleic acid . Palmitic acid has 9 carbon atoms ; oleic acid has 11 . Most natural foods contain the 9 carbon unsaturated fatty acids esters ( like stearic acid ) and decanoic acid . Exceptions include beef ( which has only 6 carbon unsaturated fatty acids and not stearic acid in large quantities ) and certain fish which have large quantities of decanoic acid . If palmitic acid and oleic acid are not present in the diet , the body breaks them down into fatty acids with fewer than 9 and fewer than 11 carbon atoms and replaces them by using the shorter ones . For example , in a healthy diet of 20 grams of carbohydrates ( which is roughly the equivalent of a 200 to 400 kcals diet ) the body will not use oleic acid to make a fat cell in the body . However , if there is not enough oleic acid in the diet , the body will use oleic acid from the diet to make these fatty acids , and then break them down into simpler fatty acids .

However , at this time , it was feared by the other kingdoms and was forced to remain isolated by treaty-lovers with neighboring countries ; the kingdom remained isolated from the rest of the world until 1280 . raw_results.original: Plumage is regularly moulted; the standard plumage of a bird that has moulted after breeding is known as the "non-breeding" plumage, or—in the Humphrey-Parkes terminology—"basic" plumage; breeding plumages or variations of the basic plumage are known under the Humphrey-Parkes system as "alternate" plumages. Moulting is annual in most species, although some may have two moults a year, and large birds of prey may moult only once every few years. Moulting patterns vary across species. In passerines, flight feathers are replaced one at a time with the innermost primary being the first. When the fifth of sixth primary is replaced, the outermost tertiaries begin to drop. After the innermost tertiaries are moulted, the secondaries starting from the innermost begin to drop and this proceeds to the outer feathers (centrifugal moult). The greater primary coverts are moulted in synchrony with the primary that they overlap.
